ICYMI here are some highlights from my Budget Address today: http://t.co/w5T3ldNwgu
Let’s not stop now. Let’s not turn back. Let’s not fail to be bold w/ the challenges ahead. Let’s finish the job.
For these past 3 years, we’ve been about results, and we are not going to change now.  And the people are better off for it.
This budget supports the expansion of the drug court program– increasing funding by over $4.5M for drug court & resulting treatment costs.
My Admin has paid particular attention to those w/ developmental disabilities. This budget includes $83M for community placement & services.
Let me be clear, I am no fan of ACA. But expanding Medicaid by 104,000 citizens is the smart thing to do for our fiscal & public health.
In fact, taxpayers will save approximately $227 million in Fiscal Year 2014 alone.
Accepting these federal resources will provide health insurance to thousands of low-income New Jerseyans and actually save taxpayers money.
Expanding Medicaid will ensure taxpayers see their dollars maximized. Federal funding will cover 100% of costs of expansion for first 3yrs.
After considerable discussion & research, we’ve decided to participate in Medicaid expansion under the Affordable Care Act.
I’m providing $5M for “Education Innovation Fund”, to implement the best, new, innovative teaching models in all of our schools.
For 3rd year in a row, I’m increasing state aid to our schools. This budget increases aid by $87M, bringing total aid to all-time record.
Today I'm proposing the establishment of a $40 million #Sandy Contingency Fund for those expenses not reimbursed by the federal government.
Our economy has been challenged by #Sandy. In face of this unprecedented emergency, we've stood together: recovering, rebuilding, restoring.
For the 4th year in a row, the budget maintains fiscal discipline we need to restore New Jersey. It's balanced & imposes no tax increases.
Watch my Fiscal Year 2014 Budget Address live at 3pm here: http://t.co/kAsOPexeL4

Our genuine thanks & gratitude goes out to the U.S. Senate for its thoughtful consideration & passage of the #Sandy disaster relief package.
From joint statement by @GovChristie, @NYGovCuomo & @GovMalloyOffice on Senate passage of #Sandy Disaster Aid Bill:
I urge the NJ Legislature to act quickly to provide real relief to New Jersey’s working families.
Along w/ this min wage increase would be direct relief for our working families through an increase in our state’s Earned Income Tax Credit
Today I called for an increase in the minimum wage by one dollar over a reasonable and balanced phase in period of three years.
In these difficult times those most impacted by challenging economic conditions are our state’s working families and they need assistance.

Today also marks MLK Jr Day of Service. I encourage New Jerseyans to honor Dr. King’s life & legacy w/ acts of service within our community.
Today we honor Dr. King’s life & work & his uncompromising commitment to peacefully working toward freedom & equality for all Americans.
His legacy stands as eternal reminder of his sacrifice & the progress he achieved & which we're obliged to protect for every citizen.
Dr. King was paradigm of strength in triumphing over adversity & racial injustice to achieve what seemed impossible to so many for so long.
A reminder that all disaster & business recovery centers will be closed for MLK Day on Monday & will return to normal hours on Tuesday.

In the year ahead, I look forward to working with all of you on that most important mission of all.
...that government can work in a bipartisan way to restore our great way of life to all New Jerseyans.
Let’s accomplish the mission of rebuilding our battered state and restoring the hope and the faith and the trust of our people...
That's our mission-to hurdle barriers no matter how high, fight elements of doubt or disaster, & leave this place better than we found it.
Let’s demonstrate once again the resilience of New Jersey’s spirit.
Let’s put the needs of our most victimized citizens ahead of the partisan politics of the day.
Let’s work together to honor the memories of those lost in Sandy.
Let’s put aside destructive politics in an election year.  Let’s put aside accusations and false charges for purely political advantage.
In this year ahead, let us prove the truth of the words I spoke to Ginjer that day.
I want to thank her for giving voice to New Jersey’s children during Sandy and helping to create a memory of humanity in a sea of despair.
I hugged her and told her not to cry—that the adults are in charge now and there was nothing to be afraid of anymore.
A house we can replace, your home is with your mom and dad.
I asked her if her parents were ok and she said they were, so I told Ginjer, you haven’t lost your home; you’ve just lost a house.
She began to cry and told me she was scared.  She told me she had lost everything; she had lost her home and her belongings.
For all I've seen & experienced as your governor, one experience will be indelibly etched in my memory.  Her name is Ginjer.
In New Jersey, we are leading the way for the nation by providing both.
In NJ, we've combined more funding w/ needed reform.  Both money and reform of our schools are essential, but neither alone is sufficient.
In K-12 education, we have made great strides, but there is much more to be done.
Last year, property taxes in New Jersey grew by only 1.7% -- the lowest rise in two decades.
Together, we enacted a 2% per year cap on growth and the interest arbitration reform that was needed to make that cap work.
The story is the same on property taxes, maybe even better.  They had increased 70% in the prior 10 years --- the most in the nation.
It hasn’t been easy, but we have done it together.  And the people of New Jersey are better off for it.
A far different picture from the prior eight years, which saw 115 increases in taxes and fees.
Four years.  Four balanced budgets.  No new taxes.  New tax relief to create nearly 75,000 new private sector jobs.
Despite the challenges that Sandy presents for our economy, I will not let NJ go back to our old ways of wasteful spending and rising taxes.
Sandy took a toll on New Jersey’s economy.  Just when we were coming back from the national recession, Sandy disrupted our economic life.
There is no question that Sandy hit us hard – but there is also no question that we’re fighting back with everything we’ve got.
NJ DOE has worked night and day to get schools re-opened right away, all while maintaining our commitment to a full 180-day school year.
Our New Jersey D.O.T. has been one of the busiest agencies – removing over 4,400 truckloads of debris from state and local roads.
We have worked with the Small Business Administration to secure nearly $189 million in loans for thousands of home and small businesses.
We have helped get temporary rental assistance for 41,000 New Jersey families.
We've overseen the removal of over 2.5 million cubic yards of debris to date and counting.  17 towns have already completed debris removal.
We have directed our Department of Environmental Protection to streamline approvals for restoring critical infrastructure.
We have secured $20 million from the Federal Highway Administration for emergency repair of our roads, bridges and tunnels.
We’ve requested the federal government to pay 100% of the costs of the significant debris removal that we require.
We have created a cabinet-level position to coordinate the State’s efforts across every agency.
Let there be no mistake:  much work still lies ahead.  Damage that comes only once in a century will take in some cases years to repair.
So make no mistake.  New Jersey’s spirit has never been stronger.  Our resolve never more firm.  Our unity never more obvious.
We have stood with the citizens  of other states in their times of need—now I trust that they will stand with us.
We're thankful to the people of America for honoring the tradition of providing relief.
The people of NJ are in need, not from their own actions but from an act of God that delivered a natural, human, & financial disaster.
One thing I hope everyone now clearly understands—New Jersey will never stand silent when our citizens are being short changed.
We now look forward to what we hope will be quick Congressional action on a full, clean Sandy aid bill and to enactment by the President.
Our pride in our state in our moment of loss and challenge is reflected in the eyes of these extraordinary people.
New Jerseyans are among the toughest, grittiest & most generous people in America. These citizens are a small example of that simple truth.
Thank you to Tracey and Jay for saving lives and making a difference.
In the process, they saw dozens of others stranded.  They turned back around and, one by one, saved over 50 of Jay’s father’s neighbors.
Not content to wait, they put on their wet suits, got in their row boat and rescued Jay’s dad.
Concerned about Jay’s father, they tried to reach him and could not.
In Brick, Tracey Keelen and Jay Gehweiler watched as the flood waters consumed their town.
Swimming through flood waters to save lives—thank you Marsha for setting such a great example.
Facing several feet of water on her flooded street, she swam to higher ground and got to the hospital for a 12-hour shift.
She could have gotten herself to safety & forgotten about her colleagues at the community medical center and most importantly her patients.
In Toms River, Marsha Hedgepeth, an emergency room technician, had the day off when Sandy hit her hometown.
Moonachie’s citizens were saved because he put them first.  Frank, thanks for your bravery.
